item.title: "There's no reason for us to hide anything", says Blizzard, with its best trustworthy expression, as World of Warcraft console speculation begins agai
item.content:encoded:
Another year, another batch of 'World of Warcraft could be coming to console' speculation. The instigator this time: the upcoming World of Warcraft expansion Midnight, which seems to be providing Blizzard with a time-and-place to snip away game add-ons and simplify the combat experience. Speculation says this is being done to prepare the game for a long-awaited console release.

Weight has been added to this argument by a couple of things. One, that Blizzard is owned by Microsoft, which of course makes Xbox and is now actively engaged in spreading its games to as many other platforms as it can, including PlayStation 5. And two, that Microsoft came out recently and suggested the next Xbox will work a lot like a PC. Given that, WoW on console seems to make sense.

But Blizzard has poured cold water on the speculation. WoW game director Ion Hazzikostas told the Unshackled Fury podcast that, "There's no reason for us to hide anything about this. If we were actively working towards bringing WoW to consoles, or a bunch of other platforms, we'd be saying, 'We're actively working towards it; we know we have a lot of work to do but it's a place where we want to land.'

"Our focus remains right now on the PC-based experience," Hazzikostas said.

It's a strong reply but WoW on console remains a perennial debate surrounding the 20-year-old game. I recall asking WoW executive producer Holly Langdale a year ago whether a console release could finally be happening, following the Microsoft acquisition, and her answer was intriguingly cagey.

"I will say nothing's impossible," Langdale told me at the time, smiling. "I can't say anything more than that." Then, she laughed and started to say something but stopped herself and instead said: "No, that's all I'll say." Then she laughed again.

Consoles are in a completely different place to where they were in 2004/5 when World of Warcraft launched. Not only are they technically more capable but their internet infrastructure and network services have improved dramatically. Plus, Blizzard already runs services like Overwatch across multiple platforms. However, in terms of size, World of Warcraft is many orders of magnitude bigger.

But putting MMOs on consoles is not impossible. Final Fantasy 14 managed it, to great success, and The Elder Scrolls Online has long been playable there too. What will it take, I wonder, for Blizzard and Microsoft to make the move? Or rather: what's the hold-up?

World of Warcraft: Midnight, the second expansion in the Worldsoul Saga trilogy, is due sometime next year. More excitingly, player housing is being added to the game after all these years, in December, in an ambitious system Blizzard is describing as "a sociological experiment".



https://www.eurogamer.net/theres-no-reason-for-us-to-hide-anything-says-blizzard-with-its-best-trustworthy-expression-as-world-of-warcraft-console-speculation-begins-again

item.title: No, Dawn French isn't eating Pokémon in the new M&S Christmas ad
item.content:encoded:
That would be Onix-eptable.

Marks and Spencer has released its new Christmas-flavoured food ad for the year, with Dawn French taking a starring role as one of many stuck in a traffic jam on their way home for some festive fun.

Ok, that's very nice and all Victoria, but what has this to do with Pokémon? Eurogamer is a site about video games, after all (I mean, the clue's in the name). Well, it is because I was watching the M&S trailer this morning with my coffee, and when I popped on the subtitles, I got a rather amusing surprise.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

At one point during the trailer, Dawn holds a plate of food above the masses gathered in the back of M&S's very plush food lorry, but she is a little unsure what she actually has in her hands. A fairy companion then whispers in her ear, before Dawn proclaims this is, in fact, a plate of pork and mushroom pâté by Tom Kerridge. How jolly!

Except, the subtitles on YouTube can't quite hear her properly, and instead proclaim the Vicar of Dibley actor is presenting a plate of Pokémon food pâté. I checked on another site with a video embedded, and again the subtitles got a little confused, this time instead suggesting Dawn was holding up a delicious Pokémon Shoe. Mmm… yummy…

Anyway, this all amused me, so I wanted to spread some silly kind of Christmas joy your way on this rather overcast Thursday afternoon, and decided to share it with you.

As for Pokémon when they are not being plated up in the back of a lorry by hungry and stressed travelers, the latest video game release made its debut just a couple of weeks ago.

"Lumiose City could do with work, but Pokémon Legends: Z-A is a much more tightly focused - and delightfully goofy - return to better form," our Chris wrote in Eurogamer's three star Pokémon Legends: Z-A review. "At least by modern Pokémon's standards."

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/no-dawn-french-isnt-eating-pokemon-in-the-new-ms-christmas-ad

item.title: The missing-in-action second-half of the Ark animated TV series has reappeared! Oh, with a formal delay
item.content:encoded:
Good news: the second part of the Ark animated television show has reappeared, having once been promised for the latter part of 2024 but never materialising. The bad news: it's been officially delayed.

However, it's not a ridiculous wait we're facing. Part 2 of the Ark: The Animated Series will apparently air sometime in 2026, according to the Ark X account. "Thank you for your patience," the tweet ended.

The first part of the Ark animated series aired on Paramount+ in 2024, and told the story of

palaeontologist Helena Walker, who suddenly found herself - like a player in the game - awake on an island filled with dinosaurs. Not a bad set of circumstances given her profession, although, you know, with the possible danger of death. The second part of the series will continue Helena's journey as she apparently "levels-up to learn the truth", said the Ark X account. (That it's all a game?)

The TV series had a surprisingly star-studded cast, including Oscar winner Michelle Yeoh, not-a-good-singer-but-a-great-gladiator Russell Crowe, Elliott Page, Karl Urban, David Tenant and many more. I haven't seen it myself but aggregator site Rotten Tomatoes tells me the series had a middling response.

Delays have become something of a taint for the Ark series in general, the most notable being for the big game-sequel Ark 2, which was once promised for 2023 but then disappeared. A recently released expansion, Ark: Lost Colony - which follows Michelle Yeoh's character from the TV series - was released in June as a way to bridge the gap until the sequel reappears.

Ark 2

Xbox Series X/S, PC

See 1 more
Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/the-missing-in-action-second-half-of-the-ark-animated-tv-series-has-reappeared-oh-with-a-formal-delay

item.title: Snowy Resident Evil film set photos give credence to major plot leak
item.content:encoded:
Set photos from the upcoming Resident Evil film from Weapons director Zach Cregger show a very snowy Raccoon City.

Filming for the adaptation kicked off earlier this year in Prague, and now thanks to The Prague Reporter we can all take a little peek at what Cregger is cooking up for us all. The snow dusting the streets on the set suggests that the film will be set during the winter season in Raccoon City, a key location in the Resident Evil games, and lends credence to an earlier rumour regarding the adaptation's plot (I won't spoil it here).

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

As you can see in the images below, Cregger's take on Resident Evil features an establishment called Oak Street Diner. This could be a little nod to Tall Oaks, a town in Resident Evil 6. One of the bus signs also points to Central Station, which pops up in the games.

"In the Karlín neighborhood of Prague 8, an action scene involving snow, gunfire, explosions, and fast driving was filmed from Oct. 29-Nov. 2," the publication wrote. "Residents and visitors passing through the area were greeted with a light cover of snow throughout the week as production on Resident Evil took place primarily during the night hours."

Cregger previously confirmed his take on the Resident Evil film will tell an original story, but will still be "true to the experience of the games". At this time, he added the film "lives" in the world of Resident Evil 2 and 3. That being said, Cregger said his adaptation "adheres more to the tone of 4". The filmmaker has not seen any of the previous Resident Evil film adaptations himself.

Cregger - whose other work includes 2022's Barbarian, which our Matt describes as "wonderfully unpredictable" - was first announced to be helming the next Resident Evil movie in March of this year.

The upcoming Resident Evil film is expected to be released on 18th September, 2026.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/snowy-resident-evil-film-set-photos-give-credence-to-major-plotstory-leak
